Singapores First Laminated Identity CardsThe National Registration Act in 1966 introduced Singapores first laminated ICs - pink for Citizens and blue for Permanent Residents.The IC was laminated to prevent illegal modification of photos and particulars, and featured unique serial numbers for each holder.Did you know? Singapores first President, Yusof Ishak, received the very first IC number: S0000001/I!Today, you can see this remarkable piece of Singapores history at ProjectCitizens The First Million, a tribute to independent Singapores founding generation, by the and the National Heritage Board. View a larger-than-life version of the 1966 IC at the showcase, and while you are there, reflect on what it means to be Singaporean and what our role will be in building Singapores future.Do you or a senior you know have a story to share? The Founders Memorial is collecting stories from our founding generation of citizens that bring to life their contributions, hopes and dreams, and the values they lived out in our nation-building years. Visit the Founders Memorialat to find out more.ICA ICAHeritageSecureBordersSafeSG GuardiansOfOurBorders

To manage the increasing cargo volume and provide a more seamless cargo clearance experience for our industry partners, ICA has been transforming the cargo clearance process under the New Clearance Concept for Cargo (NCC Cargo).In March 2023, we introduced paperless clearance for conventional cargo across all air, land, and sea checkpoints.Drivers and traders now simply submit their vehicle number and Cargo Clearance Permits (CCP) number through the MylCA mobile app before reaching the checkpoint.This paperless system has reduced cargo clearance time from an average of seven minutes to just five minutes per vehicle - a 30% improvement. Our officers can now access all necessary information through backend systems, eliminating the need for physical permits and significantly streamlining the process for everyone.ICA ICAHeritageSecureBordersSafeSG GuardiansOfOurBorders

: Launched on 1 April 2004 to mark ICAs first anniversary, Insight ICA was a tribute to the rich heritage of Singapores immigration, registration and border security functions. It brought together, for the first time, the histories of the Singapore Immigration, National Registration Department, and Customs & Excise Department.In May 2023, we created our digital Heritage Gallery on ICAs website to provide the public with easier access to our stories.Our move to the new ICA Services Centre (ISC) on 7 April 2025 paves the way for a new chapter with Securing Our Borders, Safeguarding Our Home an interactive heritage display. Come explore and rediscover the legacy that continues to shape our nation.ICA ICAHeritageSecureBordersSafeSG GuardiansOfOurBorders

- Formed in December 2003, ICAs sea-going Anti-Smuggling Teams (AST)s role was to conduct vital sea surveillance and intelligence operations to safeguard Singapore against security threats and contraband smuggling through cargo inspections on targeted vessels entering our waters. In April 2016, the ASTs functions were transferred to the Police Coast Guard (PCG) as part of Integrated Checkpoints Command (Sea)'s transformation. But did you know? The AST had its roots in ICAs predecessor, the Customs & Excise Department's (CED) Harbour Branch. Back then, Big Ship Party teams boarded vessels at sea to conduct inspections. Thank you to all officers who have served in these roles! ICA ICAHeritageSecureBordersSafeSG GuardiansOfOurBorders

[In Pictures] Travellers can now enjoy passport-less immigration clearance at the newly upgraded Tanah Merah Ferry Terminal! Similar to the processes at Changi Airport, Singaporeans can clear immigration by simply using their biometrics without the need to present their passports. Foreign travellers can also enjoy passport-less clearance at departure! However, dont forget to still bring along your passport and submit your SG Arrival Card within 3 days before arrival! SecureBordersSafeSG GuardiansOfOurBorders

29 July 2011, ICA launched eLobby, a one-stop self-service facility featuring kiosks including iReturn and iCollect. These self-service e-kiosks enabled customers to use ICAs e-Services for transactions, eliminating the need for paper forms or in-person applications over the counter.ICA leveraged technology and enhanced digital accessibility to provide public with the convenience of accessing our services from their personal devices anytime, anywhere. This led to the retirement of our self-service kiosks at eLobby in 2020, marking another milestone in our digitalisation journey.ICA ICAHeritageSecureBordersSafeSG GuardiansOfOurBorders

Let's journey back to the early 1990s when the ICA Building at 10 Kallang Road was under construction. The construction began in 1993 and was officially opened in March 1998. It was known as Singapore Immigration & Registration (SIR) Building and was later renamed ICA Building after ICA was formed on 1 April 2003, following a merger between SIR and the checkpoint functions of Customs & Excise Department.This building stands witness to ICAs transformation over the years. With the new ICA Services Centre, which is located next to the ICA Building, ICA will continue to enhance our service delivery. Stay tuned!ICA ICAHeritageSecureBordersSafeSG GuardiansOfOurBorders

- In 2013, ICA revolutionised convenience of document collection with iCollect, the first-ever unmanned machine for secure self-collection of identification documents -Singapore passports, identity cards and Long-Term Pass cards. The design for iCollect was inspired by a jukebox and enabled using fingerprint biometric verification and robotics. It earned multiple accolades before ceasing operations on 1 October 2021.The iCollect paved the way for the Integrated Smart Document Management System (iSMART), coming in 2025 at our new ICA Services Centre. The iSMART is an end-to-end solution that sorts, tracks, stores and conveys documents. Leveraging biometrics and robotics, iSMART will allow customers to enjoy appointment-free and seamless collection of their identity cards and passports.ICA ICAHeritageSecureBordersSafeSG GuardiansOfOurBorders

: Once, our officers at Changi Airport sat behind manual counters to perform immigration clearance. Today, known as Assessment & Investigation officers, they manage operations at multiple automated immigration clearance lanes, ready to assist travellers and respond to incidents.ICA has transformed travellers experience with the use of automated lanes, offering a seamless, efficient and secure immigration process with passport-less clearance. Our officers have evolved too, upgrading from static posts for dynamic roles that keep our borders safe.Take a trip down memory lane and see how our officers at the airport have evolved over the years.ICA ICAHeritageSecureBordersSafeSG GuardiansOfOurBorders

Flashback to 2006: The launch of Biometric Identification of Motorbikers System (BIKES) at Tuas and later in 2007 at Woodlands Checkpoint revolutionised immigration clearance for riders with the use of fingerprint biometrics.Enhanced in 2010, pillion riders can also clear immigration at these BIKES lanes, streamlining the clearance process for Singaporeans, Malaysian Singapore Permanent Residents, and Long-Term Pass holders. Passport in, thumbprint scanned, and off you go!Today, we say goodbye to passport scans. With QR Code, clearance time is reduced by about 30%. Its the power of technology!ICA ICAHeritageSecureBordersSafeSG GuardiansOfOurBorders

The current Woodlands Checkpoint was officially opened in July 1999, replacing the old Woodlands Checkpoint built in the 1970s. Did you know it is 3 times larger compared to the previous one, covering an area equivalent to 31 football fields? Construction of the checkpoint began in 1996. The expansion was essential to accommodate the growing numbers of travellers, boosting the capacity from 64 to 150 clearance lanes. The checkpoint was designed with three distinct levels one for cars and motorcycles, one for buses and one for lorries making clearance much more efficient. Today, Woodlands Checkpoint clears 300,000 travellers daily, and as many as 340,000 travellers on long weekends and public holidays. Stay tuned for the upcoming redevelopment of Woodlands Checkpoint, with construction starting in 2025. This redevelopment aims to significantly enhance the checkpoints capacity and efficiency, and thereby improving the traveller experience! ICA ICAHeritageSecureBordersSafeSG GuardiansOfOurBorders

- In 1998, the Singapore Immigration & Registration (SIR), one of ICAs predecessor organisations, was born from the merger between the National Registration Department (NRD) and Singapore Immigration (SI), aiming to provide more seamless and enhanced services to the public. The merger was no SIR-prise. A year prior, both SI and NRD had already moved to the SI Building at 10 Kallang Road, paving the way for their merger. With the merger, the building was renamed the SIR Building. SIR introduced several groundbreaking initiatives one of which was the Application for Passport Online Electronic System (APPLES). Launched 22 years ago, APPLES was a first-of-its-kind portal that made it possible for Singaporeans to apply for their passports anytime, anywhere. Today, as ICA, online applications remain a cornerstone of the services we offer to Singaporeans and visitors alike. ICA ICAHeritageSecureBordersSafeSG GuardiansOfOurBorders

Did you know that there was a time when Singaporeans could collect passports at Outram Road? In 1976, ICAs predecessor organisation, Immigration Department took over the former Coroners Courts Building at 240 Outram Road, setting up the Restricted Passport Centre that specially catered to the applications and issuance of the blue Singapore restricted passports. This is in addition to the other issuing centres at Empress Place and South Quay, the Woodlands Checkpoint, selected community centres and the General Post Office in Fullerton Building. The Restricted Passport Centre ceased operations in December 1994, amid a steady decline in restricted passport applications. After 1994, the Outram Road building was occupied by preschools. In 2024, it was announced that the former Restricted Passport Centre would be demolished to make way for future developments. Did you have the blue passport, or have you visited the Restricted Passport Centre at Outram Road? Share with us your memories in the comments! ICA ICAHeritageSecureBordersSafeSG GuardiansOfOurBorders

Smuggling animals into Singapore is illegal and cruel. Animals suffer in cramped spaces leading to severe medical issues, and sadly, some dont make it.ICA works closely with at the checkpoints to combat such smuggling. If you want to get a pet, make sure you get them from licensed pet shops with official documentation, such as permits and health certificates. GuardiansOfOurBorders SecureBordersSafeSG

If you want to get a pet, make sure you get them from licensed pet shops with official documentation, such as permits and health certificates. GuardiansOfOurBorders SecureBordersSafeSG

: Since its official opening in 1924, the Causeway has facilitated the flow of people and goods across the Straits of Johor, building connections across borders. As one of the worlds busiest land crossings, Woodlands Checkpoint has also witnessed the history of the Causeway over the years.Following Singapores independence in 1965, Woodlands Checkpoint then known as the immigration-customs-police complex was constructed and completed in June 1967 to introduce full immigration control on travellers entering Singapore by land.Keen to find out more stories about the Causeway? Take a trip down the memory lane by visiting the National Heritage Boards exhibition, The Causeway: A Century of Connections launched today! It is open to the public at Woodlands Civic Centre from now till 27 July 2024!ICA ICAHeritageSecureBordersSafeSG GuardiansOfOurBorders

' () Did you know that ICAs predecessor organisation, the Immigration Department used to have an office at the National Stadium? The office was called the Data Processing Centre which processed the Disembarkation/Embarkation (D/E) cards, commonly known as "white cards".Batches of D/E cards were sent daily from the checkpoints to the DPC for data entry and record keeping, which was a laborious process.Today, travellers no longer need pen and paper for the "white card" as the use of paper DE card has been discontinued since March 2020. Instead, they can conveniently submit the SG Arrival Card (SGAC) with health declaration via MyICA mobile app 3-days prior to their arrival in Singapore.ICAHeritage SecureBordersSafeSG

- Our identity card (IC) is an important document. If it lands in the wrong hands, it can be used for illegal purposes, which is why it is necessary to report the loss and apply for a replacement within 14 days. In the past, IC holders had to physically make a trip down to ICA Building, or to the National Registration Department office, to report the loss of and apply for the replacement of their IC. Some losses also required the holder to make a police report to account for the loss.Now, the public can report the loss of IC easily via MyICA mobile app or the ICA website, bringing about greater convenience to Singapore residents. Find out how the reporting of the loss and replacement of IC has evolved over the years. Photo 1: Reporting the loss and replacement of ICs at then National Registration Office at Empress Place in the 1980s.Photo 2: IC replacement counter at then National Registration Department at Colombo Court in 1992.Photo: Ministry of Information and the Arts Collection, courtesy of National Archives of SingaporePhoto 3: The e-Service for the reporting and application for replacement of lost IC was introduced on 9 October 2021. This e-Service can be accessed anytime, anywhere on MyICA app and the ICA website.ICAHeritage SecureBordersSafeSG

What our car travellers see during immigration clearance at Woodlands Checkpoint has changed over the years from open counters in 1960s to red booths in 1990s to QR code scanners at the counters today. Take a trip down memory lane to witness how the sights of immigration clearance for car travellers have evolved. Photo 1: Immigration clearance with open counters for car travellers in late 1960sPhoto 2: Beige-coloured immigration clearance booths in late 1970sPhoto 3: Red immigration clearance booths in early 1990sPhotos 4 and 5: Today, car travellers see QR code scanners at the counters and are able to clear immigration using QR codes in lieu of their passports For more of such content, visit the digital ICA Heritage Gallery at icaheritage guardiansofourborders

Leap through the Eras: Counter Services at Empress Place and Pidemco Centre In the past, members of the public visiting the Immigration Department, one of ICAs predecessor organisations, needed to queue and wait for services at the counter of its Empress Place office. The office was non-airconditioned and long standing queues were common occurrences. In 1986, the Immigration Department moved to Pidemco Centre at South Bridge Road. The new premises changed the way counter service was administered. The public were able to sit in air-conditioned halls and wait for their queue number to be flashed on the electronic number boards, instead of having to stand and wait for their turn at the Empress Place office. ICA has been digitalising our processes and services to provide a No Fuss, No Visit and No Waiting service experience for our customers! Get ...Ready for It. Follow us on an Eras Tour of ICA heritage at ICAHeritageGuardiansOfOurBorders

Did you know that the Immigration Department had a separate Field Division previously located at 86 East Coast Road? Known as the Enforcement Division today, the former Immigration Field Division (IFD) Headquarters was the enforcement arm of the Immigration Department, one of ICAs predecessor organisations.The IFD Headquarters was set up initially at the CID Building at Robinson Road but relocated in 1989 to the East Coast Road compound, which formerly housed the Joo Chiat Police Station.The IFD Headquarters was later relocated to the current ICA Building at 10 Kallang Road in 1997, then known as the Singapore Immigration (SI) Building. The East Coast compound was also later redeveloped and is now a commercial establishment as part of Katong Square.Today, ICA continues to safeguard Singapores security by enforcing our laws and regulations on immigration and registration. : Immigration Field Division HQ at 86 East Coast Road : A security pass of an Immigration Field Division HQ staffICA ICAHeritage GuardiansOfOurBorders

Retired INSP Sharif, Principal Trainer, Training Command.Whats the big deal about smuggling cigarettes? Retired INSP Sharif says, It is not about the contrabands, but the mode of smuggling that is a threat. What if the smugglers used the same smuggling method but change from contrabands to drugs, weapons, or explosive items? Youll never know if these will reach your family or loved ones. To me, someone has to do the job!ICA SecureBordersSafeSG GuardiansOfOurBorders

# Did you know Singaporeans could collect their passports at Joo Chiat Complex in the 1980s? In 1984, ICAs predecessor organisation, the Immigration Department set up an office at Joo Chiat Complex to decentralise its services. This was to serve Singaporeans residing in the East and to relieve the passport issuance workload of the Immigration Departments Head Office at Empress Place.Today, ICA continues to provide convenience to Singaporeans by allowing them to collect their passports at post offices located island-wide.Have you visited the Immigration Department at Joo Chiat Complex before? Let us know in the comments!For more of such content, check out the digital ICA Heritage Gallery at ICAHeritageGuardiansOfOurBorders

A Train Ride Down Memory Lane In the past, passengers travelling to Malaysia by rail had to board the train at the Tanjong Pagar Railway Station. The train checkpoint was later relocated to Woodlands to centralise immigration, customs and security clearance for all land traffic, including rail traffic, into Singapore. In 2011, Malaysian rail operator Keretapi Tanah Melayu Berhad (KTMB) station began operating at Woodlands Train Checkpoint, marking the closure of Tanjong Pagar Railway Station. Do you also have pictures or memories of the old Tanjong Pagar Railway Station? Share with us in the comments! For more of such content, check out the digital ICA Heritage Gallery at ICAHeritageGuardiansOfOurBorders

For decades, services centre officers were specialised in their duties. Mostly stationed behind counters, they provided services for citizens, permanent residents and foreign visitors. Customers needed to queue at various counters sometimes from one level to another, to be accorded different services. With the digitalisation of processes and move towards digital documents, many of these services are now accessible online. This paves the way for the enhancement of officers job scopes to include tasks such as case assessments, and handling of unique cases and interviews. With the new integrated ICA Services Centre (ISC) slated to be completed next year, services centre officers will also undertake job roles such as on-the-ground Service Ambassadors. As seamless and personalised customer services remain instrumental to the ISC experience, these Service Ambassadors are equipped and ready to render assistance to anyone who approaches them with enquiries about ICAs products and services. icaheritage guardiansofourborderssecureborderssafesg

Checkpoint Officers Then and NowAs you breeze through immigration via the automated clearance lanes, you will see that most of our officers are no longer at the manual counters but on the move, providing support to travellers who need assistance and looking out for dubious travellers.In the past, it was common to see officers stationed behind counters as they conducted manual immigration clearance, ensuring border security.Today, automated immigration clearance is the norm with the implementation of the New Clearance Concept (NCC), which aims to make immigration clearance more seamless, secure and efficient.As Guardians of Our Borders, our roles continually evolve. Our officers now undertake enhanced job roles such as Assessment & Investigation (A&I) officers. They oversee operations at the automated lanes, to ensure only genuine travellers enter Singapore.ICAHeritage secureborderssafesg GuardiansOfOurBorder

Birth registration has come a long way, from being painstakingly handwritten in a logbook in nineteenth century to being done online via a personal device today. Birth registration began in 1869 but was voluntary. Then, birth records were first handwritten in a logbook to form the Register of Births. In 1938, birth registration became compulsory with the enactment of the Registration of Births and Deaths Ordinance. From 1985, birth information was recorded in a computer system and computer-printed certificates were issued. Births in Singapore can now be registered online, anytime, anywhere, since the commencement of online birth registration in 2018. Since May 2022, parents are issued with digital birth certificates, which can be downloaded and stored conveniently on their personal devices, in place of physical ones. ICAHeritageGuardiansOfOurBorders

Did you know Singapores automated immigration clearance lanes for travellers were implemented 26 years ago? Back in 1997, the automated lanes were known as the Immigration Automated Clearance System (IACS). Only registered frequent travellers, with an access card that contained ones fingerprint data, could use these lanes. Over the years, ICA continued to innovate and enhance our automated lanes, to strengthen security and efficiency. Last December, ICA introduced the Special Assistance Lanes (SAL) at selected passenger halls at Changi Airport, allowing family groups of up to four persons and travellers in wheelchairs to enjoy the convenience of automated immigration clearance. Find out how the automated immigration clearance lanes have evolved over the years! Picture 1: IACS and its access card in 1997. Picture 2: The enhanced IACS (eIACS) was rolled out in 2006 to allow Singapore citizens to clear immigration with their machine-readable passports without prior registration. Picture 3: The Multi-Modal Biometrics System, which uses iris and facial biometrics as primary identifiers for immigration clearance, was implemented in 2020 at all checkpoints. Picture 4: SALs were introduced in 2022. ICAHeritageguardiansofourborders

In two days time, ICA will celebrate its 20th anniversary. But did you know that its history can be traced to the colonial days when the first ordinances governing quarantine and banishment were passed? ICA was formed on 1 April 2003 to enable a more coordinated and quicker response to any security threat or crisis, against the looming terror threats then. Today, it is an organisation that secures our borders and keeps Singapore safe and connected to the world. Find out how ICA has evolved over the years! ICAHeritageGuardiansOfOurBordersHappy20thICA

Today, it is an organisation that secures our borders and keeps Singapore safe and connected to the world. Find out how ICA has evolved over the years! ICAHeritageGuardiansOfOurBordersHappy20thICA

Training Over the Past 20 years The former ICA Academy, established in 2004, supports the training of ICA officers in physical classrooms by means of conventional methods, though focused on using modern technological solutions such as digital learning resources. Since its move to the Home Team Academy in 2006, ICA has gradually shifted our training to blended and interactive facilitations that are aided by technology, making the learning journey more dynamic and collaborative. ICA is committed to transforming training and learning practices to ensure our officers remain knowledgeable and competent to take on challenges in todays complex security landscape. icaheritage guardiansofourborders

Today, ICA officers at Harbourfront Ferry Terminal participated in an annual ferry rescue exercise (FEREX) conducted by MPA.In this exercise scenario, a ferry collision at sea necessitated a multi-agency effort to rescue the passengers and evacuate them into Singapore for medical attention.ICA officers were quick on the scene to provide security coverage and immigration clearance as part of the rescue efforts.As guardians of our borders, ICA will continue to work hand-in-glove with our strategic partners for the safety and security of our nation.SecureBordersSafeSGGuardiansOfOurBorders

ICA has been conducting trials on paperless clearance for inbound conventional cargo using the SG Arrival Card at Air Cargo and Ports checkpoints. Cargo drivers will no longer need to present hardcopy permits and supporting documents to ICA. This reduces the time taken for cargoes to be cleared, thereby allowing industry partners to optimise resources.Hear what our stakeholder, SFS Global Logistic, has to say:With the paperless clearance initiative, we have seen significant improvement in the clearance process. Our drivers can now exit checkpoint and get the cargo checks done at a quicker time, which improve our efficiency by 30% and save paper printing by more than 50%!GuardiansOfOurBorders SecureBordersSafeSG

-- The New Clearance Concept (NCC) Cargo aims to provide a secure and seamless cargo clearance experience for industry partners, through greater use of automation and paperless clearance. It will also leverage data analytics and artificial intelligence for risk profiling of cargoes to more effectively secure Singapores borders. Hear what our stakeholder has to say: The On-the-Fly clearance allows the scanning of cargo be done en route to the gate, thereby reducing time spent on travelling and waiting at the inspection centre. This swifter process not only improves the overall clearance experience for hauliers at Tuas Port, but is also environmentally greener as the shorter vehicle idle time helps to reduce carbon emissions! - , ( & ), GuardiansOfOurBorders SecureBordersSafeSG

It will also leverage data analytics and artificial intelligence for risk profiling of cargoes to more effectively secure Singapores borders. & () Arriving travellers clearing immigration at the bus hall in Tuas Checkpoint will soon encounter our steely Guardian of our Borders on duty.RESS is a robot escort to usher travellers from the immigration counters over to secondary office areas for further assistance. Equipped with environment sensors, RESS can self-navigate around the bus hall and verbally guide travellers to follow them closely.ICA is working closely with to run the trial, and will also be seeking feedback from travellers to fine-tune the conops for improved experience. The RESS trial is expected to start from 15 Aug to 11 Nov 2022.This is part of ICAs transformation plan to harness new technologies to enhance our checkpoint operations and to provide a more secure, seamless and safer immigration clearance experience for all travellers.SecureBordersSafeSGGuardiansOfOurBordersHTScienceandTechHTXsg

DidYouKnow: When travelling to Singapore, if you do not have dutiable, controlled or prohibited items, you may proceed to the Green Channel. However, ICA officers may conduct checks on visitors baggage. If you are found with any undeclared dutiable, controlled or prohibited goods, you may be fined or prosecuted.If in doubt, you may proceed to the Red Channel to make enquiries.GuardiansOfOurBorders SecureBorderSafeSG

A gentle reminder of the prohibited items not allowed to bring into Singapore: Chewing gum and tobacco Electronic cigarettes Cigarette lighters in the shape of a pistol or revolver Controlled drugs and psychotropic substances Firecrackers Obscene publications and software Seditious and treasonable materialsGuardiansOfOurBorders SecureBorderSafeSG

On 24 June, ICA officers at Tuas Checkpoint foiled an attempt to smuggle in 1,160 cartons and 1,000 packets of duty-unpaid cigarettes via a Malaysia-registered lorry.The duty-unpaid cigarettes were uncovered when officers conducted checks on the lorry carrying a consignment of empty bottles and bottle caps. The case was referred to Singapore Customs for further investigation.As guardians of our borders, ICA will continue to stay vigilant and thwart smuggling attempts through Singapores borders.SecureBordersSafeSG GuardiansOfOurBorders

She oversees the planning, development and implementation of the Woodlands Checkpoint redevelopment project. REMINDER: All travellers (including Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents), who are not fully vaccinated and entering Singapore by air, land or sea will be required to serve a 7 day Stay-Home Notice One is considered not fully vaccinated if one is aged 13 and above (born in or before 2009) and not fully vaccinated against COVID-19 with WHO EUL vaccines.This applies even if the traveller has recovered from COVID-19 or if the traveller is certified medically ineligible for COVID-19 vaccination. For more information, please refer to the Safe Travel website.

Thursday - Conducting Security ChecksICA and its predecessors have played an essential role in securing Singapores borders. While ICA has taken on various organisational names prior to its formation in 2003, one thing remains unchanged: conducting checks to prevent the unlawful entries of illegal immigrants and prohibited/controlled items, to keep Singapore safe and secure. In 2008, two female PRC nationals attempting illegal entry into Singapore were caught during immigration checks at the arrival car bay of Woodlands Checkpoint. They were found hidden in a secret compartment of a cars rear seat. Along with the driver, the PRC nationals were immediately brought under investigation. Today, ICA continues to uphold border security, to keep Singapore safe and secure. Picture 1: An immigration officer checking for valid travel documents of commuters at Woodlands, 1967. Picture 2: Officers from Singapore Customs and Excise Department, one of ICAs predecessor organisations, conducting checks on a vehicle at Woodlands Checkpoint. Picture 3: PRC nationals were found in a cars secret compartment at Woodlands Checkpoint, 2008. ICAHeritageSecureBordersSafeSGGuardiansOfOurBorders

With the On-the-Fly Clearance, ICA's Image Analysts will be able to digitally validate permits of cargo containers while they are on-the-move. This is part of ICA's New Clearance Concept for Cargo implemented at Tuas Port. Read more on:

At Tuas Port, the enhanced Radiographic Scanning Portal (RSP) will give ICA's image analysts both the top and side views of the cargoes after passing through RSP. This allows ICA officers to better analyse the scanned images and prevent undeclared or contraband items from entering Singapore's borders.Read more on:

The Mobile Cargo Screening System (Mobile CASS) is one of the initiatives under ICA's New Clearance Concept for Cargo. With Mobile CASS, ICA officers can validate permits on the spot at the secondary checking bay without needing to return to the duty office. This reduces the waiting time for drivers who are directed to the Cargo Inspection Centre for further checks.Read more on:

ICAs passport photo requirements are based on specifications by the International Standards Organisation and the International Civil Aviation Organisation. This is in order for Singapore passports to be accepted by immigration authorities overseas.Applicants whose submitted photo does not meet the requirements will thus be required to resubmit a new photo. Some common reasons why photos are rejected include: non-white backgrounds laterally inverted images (e.g. selfie) photos more than 3 months old uneven brightness shadows/spectacle reflection/glare obstructing the applicants faceFor pointers on taking acceptable passport photos, refer to ICAs photo guidelines:

Planning on a road trip to Malaysia soon? Heres some tips to make your departure travel plans a smooth one:- Singaporeans who have travel plans in the next few months and need to renew their passports are advised to submit their applications early. Once notified that their passports are ready for collection, Singaporeans can make an appointment to collect them at any of the 27 post offices without paying any additional collection fee.- Singapore-registered vehicles that plan to depart Singapore via the land checkpoints are to observe the 3/4 tank rule. Offenders may be issued with a composition sum of up to $500, or be prosecuted in court. They will also be required to perform a u-turn if they are caught committing the offence.

For those of you who guessed Pasir Panjang Scanning Station, you are correct!Do you also know that Pasir Panjang Scanning Station (PPSS) is one of 18 sea checkpoints under ICA. There are altogether 52 ICA officers stationed at PPSS. ICA officers at PPSS work round the clock to ensure that all shipments are declared correctly and no hazardous or prohibited items are brought into Singapore via our ports. One of ICAs Protective, Analytical & Assessment Facility comprising advanced laboratories equipped with radiological and nuclear analytical capabilities is located at Pasir Panjang Scanning Station.

We are moving towards paperless notifications!Currently, ICA sends hardcopy passport renewal notices to all Singapore Citizens nine months before their Singapore passport expires.From 1 Jan 2022, Singapore Citizens will receive timely digital push notifications (email and Singpass notification or SMS), instead of the hardcopy notices. The digital notifications will similarly be sent nine months before the Singapore passport expires and Singapore Citizens can apply for their renewal seamlessly by simply clicking on the link provided.This digitalisation effort will not only reduce our carbon footprint but also provide greater convenience to the public!

Do you know that some of our airport immigration counters are equipped with passport self-scanning machines? Travellers are able to self-scan their passports, reducing physical interaction with the ICA officer. This protects both the traveller and the ICA officer from the risk of COVID-19 transmission. The re-design and retrofitting of manual immigration counters will be progressively introduced to all checkpoints, paving the way for a safer mode of clearance as Singapore reopens its borders. As an Information and Registration officer at the ICA Services Centre, my duties remain the same during this hightened alert period. However, additional safe management measures have been implemented at the workplace, where we are split into two teams. The teams are are required to be seated in different zones and on work on staggered hours. We are also strongly advised not mingle with each other unnecessarily.Before the heightened alert, there was quite a high turn out at the services centres on a daily basis. However, after the alert, I noticed that theres a decrease in the numbers who came down to ICA. With the spike in unlinked community cases and new clusters emerging in the community, these hightened measures were necessary to keep all of us safe. On our part, at the ICA Services Centres, we also continuewe continue to be vigilant and ensure that we sanitise and wash our hands often. By protecting ourselves, we protect our customers too. I would also like to encourage members of public to use our e-Services online whenever possible to limit the number of visitors from coming to ICA Building, except only for urgent matters that need to do over the counters. Stay safe, everyone!Mr. Syed Ahmad Almusawa, Citizen Services Centre (IC Unit)ICAsg SecureBordersSafeSG GuardiansOfOurBorders ICAPerspectives OfficersatWork

Here at Parcel Post Section, officers are segregated in clusters and working from home on certain days, to minimise interactions and make it easier to perform contact tracing, if necessary. With a smaller pool of officers on duty, we need to keep up with the increased load of parcels imported in, especially when our borders have been closed for quite some time. We also wear masks & gloves when handling parcels and when communicating with customers over the counter.Although there are inconveniences caused by the change in rules of engagement, I feel that this is necessary as it shows that ICA is serious in protecting our own officers during this pandemic. In ICA, teamwork is crucial as every officer has a role to play and I have learnt that keeping a positive and open mind is key, to embrace any obstacles head on, as well as to encourage and motivate my peers to remain vigilant, come what may. CI(1) Khairunnisa, Parcel Post Section ICAsg SecureBordersSafeSG GuardiansOfOurBorders ICAPerspectives OfficersatWork

We are required to don appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) during our course of work and are being allocated dedicated rest and dining areas at a specific segregated area. One of the initiatives which I feel thankful for is the implementation of video conferencing in assisting travellers on their immigration documentation as this greatly reduces any exposure we have with them especially if they are arriving from a high risk country.As a frontline officer at Airport, I am in contact with travellers arriving from high risk countries because we are the ones on the ground accessing their entry eligibility and also serving them Stay Home Notice (SHN) upon their arrival in Singapore. While the additional precautionary measures in place such as having specific places that we can have our meals at or even having our movements restricted at segregated areas might seem as an inconvenience to us, I find this heartening as it goes to show that ICA about our safety and well-being. I thus feel more assured and at ease while performing my duties during this pandemic. CI(1) Shirley Hoon, Airport Command ICAsg SecureBordersSafeSG GuardiansOfOurBorders ICAPerspectives OfficersatWork

While the additional precautionary measures in place such as having specific places that we can have our meals at or even having our movements restricted at segregated areas might seem as an inconvenience to us, I find this heartening as it goes to show that ICA about our safety and well-being. I thus feel more assured and at ease while performing my duties during this pandemic. CI(1) Shirley Hoon, Airport Command ICAsg SecureBordersSafeSG GuardiansOfOurBorders ICAPerspectives OfficersatWork

10- 2021!ICA will increase the validity period of the Singapore passport from five to 10 years. This will apply to Singapore citizens aged 16 and above, who submit their passport application from 1 October 2021. We will also keep the passport application fee at S$70.This means you wont have to renew your passport as frequently anymore!Pro tip: If your passport is expiring between now and September 2021 and you don't have to travel soon, you may wish to consider delaying your passport application till October.ICAsg SecureBordersSafeSG GuardiansOfOurBorders

On 1st April 2003, we became Immigration & Checkpoints Authority (ICA). Before ICA, Singapore Immigration (SI) took charge of immigration arrival and clearance processes, National Registration Department (NRD) managed identification and citizenship issues, while Customs and Excise Department (CED) was involved in border security and protection.ICAsg #SecureBordersSafeSG GuardiansOfOurBorders ICAHeritage
